should sync be set to True in case OVS was restarted? I mean if in original code bridges_recreated is always True when OVS is restarted, then we lose this sync setting with this patch
Agree, thanks for clarification!

if ovs is restarted it will restart polling manager (see L2521-2523 and comment there) so all ports will be treated as added and it will do kind of "sync". It was like that before adding this monitoring of recreated bridges and it was working fine. So I don't think that there is need to change that part of the logic when ovs was restarted.

I was reading _reconfigure_physical_bridges(), _do_reconfigure_physical_bridges() and setup_physical_bridges() to see if they do anything that would need to be re-done after an ovs restart. I found these two lines:

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/cb55643a0695ebc5b41f50f6edb1546bcc676b71/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py#L1566-L1567

There we install the default port drop flows. Since these are flows they will be lost during an ovs restart and here we won't reinstall them after the current change.

Do we reinstall them somewhere else or do we lose them?

If ovs is restarted it will install same flows by calling setup_physical_bridges() in L2491.
Basically those 2 cases: restart of ovs agent and recreate of physical bridge are doing almost the same things with physical bridges. The difference is that in case of ovs restart it do it with all bridges in bridge mappings and in case of recreated bridges, only for those bridges :)

See below, but I think that failure to initialize this could theoretically cause a NameError below where it might be used. Should initialize 'bridges_recreated = False' at the top of the loop around L2539 to be safe.  Doesn't look like the other variables here are used outside this block.
Good catch. I will change that

Brian, this isn't used for gate jobs, it is the default list (and order) of tests that run when you simply run "tox". So, this is the list of tests we expect developers to run and pass prior to posting a patch.

tripleoclient/utils.py.message: I wonder if there's a min/max we should consider as well in a future patch. But this is likely an improvement initially
This should also have an upper limit: on a single socket 64 core machine that would return 256, on a 64 core system with 128 threads it would return 512. Maybe something like 64 or 128?

in py3 we should use 

  len(os.sched_getaffinity(0))

https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.cpu_count

> Well, I think we've been using processor count for all
 > multiprocessing configurations ex. os_workers[1] till date and I'm
 > not sure if it makes sense to only change it here to cater to an
 > unlikely case.
 > 
 > [1]  https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/facter/os_workers.rb#L16

I think we have to think about systems with the max potential core count something like 4 socket, 64 core w/ 64 threads would result in 2048 forks evaluated at every task, though eventually capped to the max number of hosts. In a cloud with 500 nodes and forks set to >500 we'd attempt to run 500 simultaneous ssh connections, which is almost certainly going to fail with ssh issues, assuming ansible doesn't consume all available memory.

Well, I think we've been using processor count for all multiprocessing configurations ex. os_workers[1] till date and I'm not sure if it makes sense to only change it here to cater to an unlikely case. 

[1]  https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/facter/os_workers.rb#L16
Do we've cpu affinity set on the underclould for it to be different?

In my opinion, we would need a min and a max if we use Python to compute how many forks we create.
A viable minimum to run Ansible (is 1 a possible number?)
And certainly a maximum that would be reasonable at scale; taking in account the ssh connections numbers.

Very often we cap the maximum values, see examples in:
* https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/facter/os_workers.rb
* https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/master/tripleo_common/image/builder/buildah.py#L193

Setting a max value is important to do, since we acknowledge that despite high number of cpus, there are still some limits on the systemd, like networking memory and such.

So maybe we could do something like:

  env['ANSIBLE_FORKS'] = min(200, max(36, multiprocessing.cpu_count() * 4))

?
The undercloud isn't likely to be a 4 socket 64 core thing, I think we can follow up with a max cap at some point but shouldn't stop us from merging this at the moment
I don't imagine that it would be, but it could be, especially on POWER systems.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message:
Just curious, for system doesn't have FPGA, this image should not be needed, is it correct?
Could it be pulled per need?
Thanks.

Considering the FPGA can be enabled post deployment (by locking the node, add the FPGA card and unlocking it), I don't have a concern with having this image pre-pulled. The user can always remove the image from the registry using system registry-image-delete command if desired. 

We can/should consider having this image optionally pulled during bootstrap when a mechanism to pull the image, push it to registry and register it for automatic upgrade (as part of FPGA enabling) is available.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cmd/helm.py.message: this "enable, do something, disable" sequence appears to be at risk for race conditions if another thread of execution can activate or deactivate the plugins at the same time.

I have further apps to decouple and will do some additional testing around this and will restructure accordingly. 

This pattern is in use currently to support application upgrades where we have multiple app versions uploaded each with their own plugin versions, but those version have the same resource names. We are only activating the specific version that is being applied so the correct version is accessed.

This update will enable plugin access to an app that is not yet applied to extract the overrides for user manipulation.

grafana/values.yaml.message: this is already the default - why explicitly set it?

Hey John. It's not required to define these values to allow for overriding them downstream. Everything under the configuration key gets consumed and rendered in the configmap, including any additional values defined as overrides downstream. For example, if you wanted to set this cookie_secure value to true, you just need to add `cookie_secure: true` to your downstream values passed to the chart. That doesn't require them to be defined here though, as the values overrides get merged with whatever is defined in the chart, not just a replacement of defined values.

Thanks Steve, I also thought the same. But it didn't work..

conf:
   grafana:
      security:
         cookie_secure: true
         cookie_samesite: strict
         x_content_type_options: true
         x_xss_protection: true

I would encourage you to find out what's wrong with the format of your downstream overrides. I would expect that if you passed in these values to the deployment script for grafana as --set overrides instead of in the values file here, you'd see them included in the encoded contents of the grafana.ini key in the grafana-etc secret.
Thanks Steve, It allows override the values.
Thanks Steve, looks like a deployment issue and seeing issues in the older regions. Not seeing the issue in the recent deployments.  Thanks for your help!

networking_vpp/agent/server.py.message:
Your test seems dubiously optimised - you put every entry in a list, then you do 'is in a list'.  You could do every entry in a set, but I think you *should* be iterating on the raw function output to see if it matches your input.

Also, get_snat_local_ipaddresses looks like it should die - there's no reason to consider all IP addresses regardless of VRF.
So will we do this later, or will it now never be associated?  What would make this get called a second time?

I have noticed that the issue with incorrect ordering occurs only during an agent restart. The normal sequence of operation is ensure-router-interface, then associate floating ip. 

When an agent is restarted and if it receives a watch event to associate a floating ip before the router interface is ensured, it queues up the request and then after the router interface is ensured, it calls the maybe_associate_floating_ip. The case of someone never adding a router is not possible because you must add a router and ensure its interface before associating a floating ip on its interface - right?
You are right. This needs more investigation. I think we should defer this for the next release.

There's no guarantee there, though - *if* someone changes routers and this one wasn't added then it will be added at that point.  If someone never adds a router or doesn't add one for hours then this won't be re-called.
And the added() method also invokes ensure_router_interface_on_host() before invoking maybe_associate_floating_ips().

Naveen, correct me if I am wrong but _associate_floatingip() will get invoked from maybe_associate_floating_ips() which in turn is invoked from the added() method of the RouterWatcher eventlet. It is guaranteed that the RouterWatcher's added() method will be invoked sooner or later if there are FIPs.

guidelines/tags.rst.message: Thanks for this. I failed to find time to write it down (as the ML thread owner).

(Side discussion)

is there any reason we don't support to update tags in the same way as for in resource creation?

 PUT /resources/{id}
    {
        "tags": ["foo", "bar"],
    }

This is what we usually use when updating/patching an attribute.

Currently we suggest to use the root tags URL when updating tags. It make OpenStackSDK and OSC implementations a bit tricky. When updating a resource, we need to call two PUT APIs 
(the one for updating usual attributes and the other for updating tags).

I don't oppose the current way, but it would be nice if we also support to update tags via resource attribute (as we document for creating a resource in this commit).

Thought?

That's a very good point. Since they are returned along with other resource attributes, they should be able to be set the same way.

I'll add that to the agenda for the next API-SIG meeting

this seems reasonable to me. unless tags are implemented as a separate resource, being able to update them during the normal course of resource updates sounds like something we should have in the guidance as well.

roles/undercloud-setup/templates/install.message:
Hey Yatin, help me understand the problem you are looking to solve here, I'm not sure if I understand the intent.

The yum repos in play during a container update are governed by the container-prepare-param.yml file.  e.g https://4dca9d38a541907e85e1-0253beca39d73a6e7192d5b32ed5edc2.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/685184/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone/466603f/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/containers-prepare-parameters.yaml.txt.gz

If you are looking to further limit what is available to update, it should probably be handled in that config.  

I could be wrong on not understanding what you are looking to do though, so help me out.

@weshay, i am trying to achieve following:-
Goal: Restrict yum update to only the repos which are available, So in ContainerPrepareParameter repos are set like, update_repo: "gating-repo,delorean-current,quickstart-centos-ceph-nautilus", the main advantage of this goal will be seen when there is no repo available to update[1].

[1] Cases when these repos are either not available or mis configured, like in promotion jobs these repos are not there, but still container update runs and takes good amount of time.
There is an option to completely turn off the update for promotion jobs, but i don't want to do that as sometimes we want to run promotion jobs in check to test upstream fixes. So i wanted to dynamically remove the repos based on the availability.

So ideally these tasks are added to ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image role with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685431/, the reason i am trying this hack in quickstart-extras to get a case where no yum repo is available(with depends-on on ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image gating-repo get's created). I can try another hack though instead of it to achieve same effect.

Hmm may be there are better ways to handle it, but since this role(ansible-tripleo-modify-image) provides too many ways to handle the update, i wanted to do it in the role itself. But yes there can be more options which i have not considered yet.

container-images/tcib/base/base.yaml.message:
with the noted edits I was able to get base built with the following minimal command:

  openstack tripleo container image build --config-file --volume '/etc/yum.repos.d:/etc/yum.repos.d' --volume '/usr/share/kolla:/usr/share/kolla'

To make this a better user experience, I think we should fork the required kolla scripts and just store them into this repo.

this requires user input to succeed.

running the following command:

        openstack tripleo container image build

This is the error 

        Command: sudo buildah bud --format docker --tls-verify=False --logfile /tmp/container-builds/6998a731-ff23-4b35-8cf0-99ce923dbfb3/base/base-build.log -t localhost/tripleomaster/openstack-base:latest /tmp/container-builds/6998a731-ff23-4b35-8cf0-99ce923dbfb3/base
        Exit code: 1
        Stdout: ''
        Stderr: 'error building at STEP "RUN [ -d /var/tmp/yum.repos.d ] && cp -R /var/tmp/yum.repos.d/* /etc/yum.repos.d": error while running runtime: exit status 1\n'

we can solve this gpg key issue with the following changes

  tcib_pre_build: true
  tcib_gather_files:
    - '/etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-centosofficial'
    - '/etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-centostesting'

This means we could probably figure out a glob which lets us grab these files in base and copy them into place.


Copy action was done like so

  tcib_actions:
    - copy: /etc/pki /etc/pki
I think we need to either default bind mount these volumes to an appropriate location, or assume repos and gpg keys are already in the base image.

I've been able to dynamically pull the gpg keys with the following lookup

  tcib_gather_files: "{{ lookup('fileglob', '/etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-*', wantlist=True) }}"

these all assume that "/usr/share/kolla" is a bind mount.

Running the following command

    openstack tripleo container image build --volume '/etc/yum.repos.d:/etc/yum.repos.d'

results in the following error

        Command: sudo buildah bud --volume /etc/yum.repos.d:/etc/yum.repos.d --format docker --tls-verify=False --logfile /tmp/container-builds/040f1b55-99a7-4385-bf46-ced23e6aa063/base/base-build.log -t localhost/tripleomaster/openstack-base:latest /tmp/container-builds/040f1b55-99a7-4385-bf46-ced23e6aa063/base
        Exit code: 1
        Stdout: ''
        Stderr: 'error building at STEP "RUN cp /usr/share/kolla/docker/base/set_configs.py /usr/local/bin/kolla_set_configs && chmod 755 /usr/local/bin/kolla_set_configs": error while running runtime: exit status 1\n'

note the package "openstack-kolla" is not currently a dependency of anything within tripleo. Maybe we simply move the scripts we need into the directories where they're required and we can copy them into the container via the containerfile?
I'm not sure we want the /etc/pki from the host into the container. This is only useful at the build time when repos are bind mounted.

The only files copied are "/etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-*", because that's all we gather. However, it'd probably be good to extend the copy string to:

  /etc/pki/rpm-gpg:/etc/pki/rpm-gpg
This is definitely not very readable.

specs/victoria/encrypted-messages-in-que.message: can you tell more here? what attribute? how does it work?
sure，there means adding a new attribute to message object like "is_encrypted=True/False", which will let Zaqar system know this content of message is encrypted string.

1. How will the key for encryption and decryption be stored?
2. Will each queue has its own key? or the key is used global?
3. In the case:   {
    "_enable_encrypt_messages": true,
    "_enable_decrypt_messages": false
  }
    I assume users should decrypt the message by himself, right? Then how do they get the decryption key? Or how will they send the encryption key to Zaqar?

Make sense.

Geting the decription key(usually it's private key) from endpoint is dangerous.
I think there are two case:
1. Use Zaqar's key-pairs. In this case, users should not get the private key. i.e. all action is done by Zaqar.
2. Use user's key-paris. In this case, users should only upload their public key to Zaqar and decrypt the message by themself. i.e. the pricate key should not expose to others, even to Zaqar.

So in these two case, you can find that "_enable_encrypt_messages" and "_enable_decrypt_messages" are mutual exclusion. In case 1, `_enable_decrypt_messages` should be always `True`, otherwise users can not decypt the message. In case 2, `_enable_decrypt_messages` should be always `False`, since Zaqar can't decypt the message. So "_enable_decrypt_messages" is meaningless IMO.

I think only `_enable_encrypt_messages` is enough. If use global key, Zaqar will decypt the message. If use users' key, users will decypt the message.

How do you think
Totally agree, two metadata now are pretty confusing to users too.

In V Cycle, I want to just support the global key for encryption and decryption, and it will be held by Zaqar service itself. Go a step further, we can consider the Barbican Project to store and manage the key.

And users could have two ways to get the key in my mind. 1. Get the key offline from the admin user directly. 2. Zaqar could give a new endpoint to let user get the key through http/https. (Although I think it could have another security risk.)
Adding new metadata for queue is enough IMO, no need to add a new endpoint
sure. sorry for the misleading here, it's just the queue's name.
